The Buddha said: In the past, there were hundreds of deer in a herd, following the water and grass, encroaching on the human village. The king went out hunting, and they scattered in all directions.
There was a pregnant doe who went off alone. Chasing and exhausted, she lost her companions and was despondent.
At that time, she gave birth to two fawns. She left to search for food, feeling lonely and confused. She mistakenly fell into a hunter's trap, crying out in grief, unable to escape.
The hunter heard the sound and went to investigate. Seeing the deer, he was delighted and wanted to kill it.
The deer then kowtowed, begging for mercy and explaining:
'I recently gave birth to two fawns, still young and ignorant, just beginning to be confused, not knowing east from west.
I beg for a short time to return and see my fawns, to show them water and grass, to allow them to live, and to die with my two fawns, grieving to the end.
Long or short life, it is over!'
I hope you will show mercy and pity those with consciousness.
If I am granted mercy and allowed to see my child, it is truly not something a deer can repay;
Heaven blesses those with virtue, and blessings pour down without limit.
The time of being sent away will not go against the vow of faith, and when I return, I will face death. The deer's mind has no resentment.'

At that time, the hunter heard what the deer said, and he was both surprised and strange. His hair stood on end. Its extraordinary ability to speak, beyond human understanding, he immediately asked the deer, 'Are you a ghost or a spirit of the mountains and forests?
Are you not deluded, borrowing its form?
Tell me the truth and make it clear.'
The deer then replied, 'Because of the sin of greed and cruelty in my past life, I received the body of a deer.
With utmost sincerity, I think of my child, so I can speak with my mouth. I am not a ghost or spirit. I only hope you will recognize my pity and let me live and die as I please.'
The hunter, hearing this, added his words of faith, but his greedy mind was unwilling to listen. He said to the deer:
'People in the world are generally not sincere, let alone you, a deer animal?
You cherish your children and value your body, still seeking to live and escape from death. Going from death to life, how could there be a return date?
The king's order is urgent, I fear he will certainly know. Blaming me for losing the deer, I will receive a heavier punishment again.
Although my heart is not compassionate, the matter cannot be helped. I will never let you go.'
The deer was then frightened and said with bitter words:
'Although a deer is a lowly animal, I would rather die than regret it. Seeking a date to return, how dare I disobey your order?
A person receives punishment, I only beg for a temporary blessing, planted by blessings.
If I go, my children will live. If I stay, my children will die. Listen to me when I go and return, the spirit will believe my words.
What is death worth, yet to go against my heart and faith?
I think of my two children, and that is why I am so earnest.'
Born, not recognizing my mother, each will die, dividing the dead to save the young, destroying the three severe pains.'
The deer mother lowered her head and neighed, speaking a verse:
'My body is a deer, roaming and eating in the forest,
Born lowly, greedy for my body and life, unable to deliberately send myself to death.
Now coming to enter your trap, I myself will accept the knife and chopping block,
Not sparing this foul and stinking body, but only pitying my two young ones.
Only I, in my previous life, was violent and not sincere,
Not believing in the suffering of birth and death, the clarity of sin and merit.
Practicing evil, I myself invited sin, now receiving the form of an animal,
If I am granted a moment of life, I will never violate my oath of trust.'
Then the hunter heard the deer's voice of complaint, and greatly admired it!
Greedy for profit to accomplish things, not wanting to let it go, he immediately told the deer, reprimanding it, saying:

'Deceit and falsehood are unreal, and cunning is hard to believe. Empty flowers are myriad, and cunning is not one. Harming the seeds of life, violating others' crops, with guilt throwing oneself into my trap.
Now I will kill and send it to the royal kitchen for food. There is no need to lie and deceive me seeking release. With a heavy body fearing death, who can sacrifice their life?
For a person without food, it is still hard to make a promise, let alone an animal?
With a complete life escaping death, how can there be a promise to return?
You should just die, I will never let you go.'
The deer then remembered its child and knelt in front, with its two knees and head lowered, tears streaming, sadly pleading and moaning, repeating the verse:
'Although my body is a deer, I do not understand the ways of benevolence and righteousness,
How can I receive your compassionate grace, leave and not return?
Better to endure the pain of being torn apart, than to remain with deceit and falsehood,
Pitying the two sons' poverty, I borrowed for a short while.
Due to past karma, I naturally received an animal body,
And was not believed by others, Calamities and misfortunes naturally befit me.
This is still inviting the future, Wishing to escape the form of an animal,
I bare my heart and reveal my sincerity, I wish to listen to my solemn oath.
If there are evil people in the world, Causing discord among the bhiká¹£us,
Destroying stÅ«pas and Buddhist temples, And killing those who uphold the precepts,
Treasonously harming one's parents, Brothers and wives;
If I do not return, The crime is greater than this.
The ultimate crime in the world, The calamity at the end of the kalpa is not over,
Rolling around and being burned again, Going there and returning here.
It should be deeply considered, Suffering pain without end,
If I do not return, The crime is greater than this.
At that time, the hunter, hearing the words of the deer, was even more shocked and sighed:

'I only see that all the people in the world, receiving the blessings of their past lives, are born as humans, yet they are foolish, deluded, and dark, ungrateful, unrighteous, unfaithful, unfilial, and unkind. They are greedy, cruel, and without the Way. They deceive and cheat to preserve themselves. They do not know impermanence and do not recognize the Three Jewels.

The deer are just animals, yet their words are sincere and their oaths are earnest. They are different from humans, their emotions revealing their sincerity, as if clearly seen, using their experiences to discern their hearts.'
He then went forward, untied the snare, and released them.

Then, the mother deer came out of the snare and left. She looked back and ran to where her fawn was. She lowered her head, sniffed her fawn, licked its body, was both happy and sad, hesitated and lingered, sighed and whimpered, and spoke a verse in both joy and sorrow:
The mother deer said: 'All kindness and affection come together, all due to causes and conditions.
When they come together, there will be separation, impermanence is hard to last for long.
Now I am your mother, always fearing I cannot protect myself,
Born in the world, there are many fears, life is like dew on grass.'

Having spoken this verse, the mother deer then took her two fawns into the forest, to separate and eat the crops, showing them good water and grass, warning and instructing them, teaching them the way of life.
Thinking of parting with her orphaned fawns, tears fell like rain, she cried out in grief, speaking a verse of farewell:
In past lives, I deceived and cheated, owed debts and clung to affection,
Cruel and violent towards the lives of beings, I myself stole and taught others to kill.
The body acts as if a shadow follows, today I will receive it,
Finishing the old, not creating new, I will return to fulfill that appointment.
Disobeying the Buddha's teachings, lacking faith, going against the teacher's admonitions,
Self-willed, greedy, and insatiable, letting emotions run wild, indulging foolish thoughts.
The karmic retribution is to become an animal, to be someone's livestock,
Not daring to resent one's fate, not deceiving again until the end of one's life.
Greedily seeking, taking the wrong path, killing and stealing in past lives,
In every life, becoming an animal, pursued by past karma.
Bound and shackled, about to die, terrified, losing vitality,
Using the words of the Three Jewels, seeing through and letting go of all affection and love.
I went out in the morning but did not meet anyone, mistakenly falling into a hunter's trap,
About to be slaughtered, broken and suffering the retribution of past wrongs.
Remembering you came to beg for mercy, now I will return to my death,
Feeling pity for your small orphaned pair, strive to live on your own.
When walking, rely on the herd, when resting, rely on the herd's center,
When eating, you should follow your companions. When sleeping, you should be startled and get up.
Be careful not to go alone. Do not run and eat by the roadside.
After saying this, we will part forever. Even if we die, we will not return.

At that time, after the doe mother said this verse, she said goodbye to her children, lingering and turning back again and again, lowering her head, sighing, crying with emotion, and left with her back bent.
The two children cried sadly, longing for their mother, following behind her, exhausted, getting up again, crying and calling out, and spoke a verse, saying:
Greedy for desire and affection, born as a mother's child,
Since coming into this body, receiving a lowly animal's life.
How can we see her abandoned, her life cut off, dying here?
Longing for our mother, our feelings are cut off. We beg to be together and die.
We think since our birth, we do not know east from west,
Thinking of our mother's pity for us, we should repay the kindness of nurturing with milk.
How can we bear to live long apart, never to see each other again in this world?
Thinking of our mother's suffering for our sake, it would be shameful for us to live alone and complete.
Without blessings, we receive animal forms; meager blessings lead to misfortune and harm.
Having just been born, we are confused; we should see our mother abandoned early.
All who are born will die; sooner or later we will face it.
Today's hardship should be shared with our mother.
Then, after the fawn spoke this verse, its mother sadly lowered her head and wept, grieving and lamenting. She turned her head to look back, raised her voice in a sorrowful cry, and said to her fawn:
You should return and not come.
I will end my life and take responsibility for it.
Do not let mother and child die an untimely death together.
I am willing to die, but it would be a pity for you, who have not yet learned that in the impermanence of the world, we will all be separated.
I myself have little fortune, and you were born without blessings. Why do you grieve and wail, only increasing worry and trouble?
You should just quickly go and finish paying off your debts now.
The mother deer also called out, speaking a verse for her child, saying:ğŸ”½I previously sat in greed and love,
now receiving a lowly animal body,ğŸ”½in the world, those born all have death,
there is no escape from the calamity of not ending.ğŸ”½Controlling the mind, once free from greed,
only then is there great peace,ğŸ”½rather go to die with utmost sincerity,
never deceive and endanger life.
Then, the fawn heard the mother's verse sound, and even more sadly and longingly called out, following her to the snare, searching east and west, and saw the hunter lying under a tree.
The mother deer went straight to his side, lowered her head and made a loud sound, waking the hunter, and spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½Throwing oneself into the real among the divided,
finishing one's life as an animal,
Seeing the release, I dare not delay, but return to the executioner's block.
The deer that were released before, now come back to die.
With kindness towards lowly animals, I get to say goodbye to my two children.
As I am about to leave, I show them water and grass, and tell them of impermanence and suffering.
Even if I die, I have no regrets, and think of their kindness, not daring to betray them.'

At that time, the hunter heard the deer's cry, speaking words of sincerity and truth, startled and immediately got up, his heart trembling, and compassion arose within him, but he had not yet been able to express it with his mouth.
The deer then lowered its head and knelt forward on both knees, again facing the hunter, happily confessing and apologizing with a verse, saying:
Your previous release of us, your virtue is greater than heaven and earth.
Lowly animals are nurtured with kindness, and I cannot bear the grief in my heart.
Everything is impermanent, joyfully accepting death in accordance with my faith,
The enmity is extinguished, and from this point on,
Your kindness and grace are difficult to forget, how could I dare to disobey your feelings?ğŸ”½Even if I were to offer a thousand apologies,
It would not be enough to repay your kindness.ğŸ”½Only by being sincere in my admonitions,
Will the blessings return naturally.ğŸ”½Today, I willingly die,
Entrusting my child to your benevolent lord.'

Then, the hunter was moved by her sincerity and fell asleep. He again heard the deer speaking in verse, all in subtle sounds, and his deep faith increased. He gave up his life and died, fulfilling the oath.
The mother and child cried sadly, following each other to the place.
'This deer's body must not be ordinary, I have seen worldly people, but I am unable to compare with it.
Although it has the body of a beast, its mind is like a divine spirit.
I have been unprincipled and cruel for a long time.
The deer established principles, speaking truthfully and not betraying, it can be a clear teaching, bowing my head to receive it;
How could I dare to give rise to a mind of harm and offense?
The hunter immediately became more respectful and polite, bidding farewell to the deer and saying in verse:
The divine deer is truly like a god, with words and vows of great aspiration,
Now my heart is filled with fear, how could I dare to inflict harm?
It would be better to kill myself, dividing my body into pieces,
How could I bear to harm a spiritual being, a descendant of the gods?
After the hunter spoke this verse, he sent the deer away with a compassionate mind, again apologizing and regretting his mistake.
The deer, seeing that it was being sent away, went to its young. The young, seeing their mother, were able to come out and run towards her, jumping and crying.

The mother and child reunited, both joyful and happy, looking up and down at each other, crying out in a mournful voice, feeling grateful for being saved, and receiving great kindness. They then looked up to thank the hunter, speaking in verse:
The lowly animal in the world should be slaughtered in the kitchen,
Immediately divided and cooked, giving the two children a break.
The treasured loved object of heaven and humans, again granted amnesty and pardoned,
Meritorious assistance accumulated to an immeasurable extent, not able to be expressed by the mouth.

At that time, the mother deer, having spoken this verse of gratitude, led her two children back to the deep forest, calling out to the herd, gathering them, settling her body in the grassy marshes, and calming herself on the steep mountain.
The hunter later deeply thought to himself:
'The deer are just animals, yet their trustworthiness and righteousness protect their bodies. Having been spared, they immediately rescue. Those who see it praise them even more.
How much more extensive is my heart in being violent?'
He immediately awakened, his mind scattered, returning to benevolence, releasing his crossbow, destroying his traps, and no longer having the thought of killing.

He went to the temple and requested to receive the precepts of a Å›ramaá¹‡a. He bowed his head and face, taking refuge in himself and confessing himself, upholding the benevolent principles, and dedicating his will to the true reality.
He then went to inform the king, explaining in detail the words of the deer.
When the king heard this, he was delighted and amazed:
The deer animal has righteousness, while I am more greedy and cruel.
Moreover, this wise deer deeply understands the teachings and knows to revere the Three Jewels;
Our country is dark and evil, following those false words.
It is truly worthy to abandon them and preserve what is forever complete.

All the people of the country heard and knew that the animal practiced righteousness and was presently granted the proof of faith, and the transformation of the Great Way was revealed without concealment.
Then, the king invited the assembly of ministers and proclaimed to the people of the country:

I was in the dark and did not distinguish true from false. I opened myself to a heretical teacher who spoke of fearing false gods, performing evil sacrifices without principle, and wantonly harming living beings;
Not as good as the deer animal, who clearly recognizes the Three Jewels.
From now on, throughout the country, the people will abandon that false teaching and all return to the true and correct.
They went to the Buddhist temple to invite the noble assembly, hoping to obtain blessings for future lives.
The ministers, officials, and citizens, both high and low, all believed in the Three Jewels and observed the five precepts and ten wholesome deeds.
For three years, the country was prosperous and peaceful, and the people all lived long and happy lives, thanks to the deer.
The Buddha said to the Venerable Ananda:
Only I, the skillful one, have practiced kindness for many eons. My kindness saves sentient beings, and their faith is like this.
At that time, the mother of the deer was me;
The two sons were Rahula and Zhulima Juli;
The king of the country was Shariputra;
The hunter was Ananda;
The border people who ran to report to the king were Devadatta.

When the Buddha had finished speaking, he emitted a great light from the calf of the deer, illuminating the east, west, north, south, the four corners, and the ten directions, each a thousand buddha-lands.

Wherever my light shines, there are transformation guides, lion seats, and jeweled lotus flowers. Sometimes I appear as a Dharma master bhiká¹£u with a physical body, sometimes as a king or the son of a wealthy man, sometimes as a lowly person among the common people, and sometimes as an animal among the multitude of living beings. Each uses the light to guide and teach the Dharma.

At that time, the merit of the deer mother's vow was used as a Dharma lesson. The sound of the Dharma entered their minds, and none did not believe and accept it. They all returned to the unsurpassed true path.
The Buddha then turned the light back and equally illuminated the entire JambudvÄ«pa, causing it to be completely penetrated. Those who received the light attained a sense of peace and security.

At that time, there were eight hundred bhiká¹£us in the assembly. Their minds were on the four paths and they had realized the path and its traces. Hearing of the deer mother's great intention arising in the midst of the animal realm, and her attainment of the path through faith, they were moved and immediately repented. They said to the Buddha:

We vow to establish the bodhisattva path with a sincere mind. May the Buddha compassionately assist and benefit us. We will carry out the practice to bear the burden of sentient beings, to rescue all, until death we will not depart. We will immediately attain the armor of the vast vow of saá¹ƒnÄha-saá¹ƒnÄha.

It is truly not something that a small path can believe and understand.
There is a doubt in the great assembly. I only wish that the World-Honored One will explain the causes and conditions to release the future!

These bhiká¹£us were once deer roaming in the kingdom. They believed and accepted the king's order to respectfully follow the Three Jewels. The deer immediately felt moved and all vowed for the unsurpassed true intention.

In the middle, they were confused and ignorant, and did not practice again. Although they encountered me and became monks, they suddenly abandoned their original vows and were confused about the Great Vehicle.
Now, hearing me speak of their past causes and conditions, their doubts are resolved, and they attain the peace of non-conceptualization. This is due to the consciousness of their past lives.
When the Buddha said this, eight hundred bhiká¹£us all attained the stage of nonretrogression;

In the crowd of warriors, eight thousand people saw and understood, eliminated heedless conduct, and all gave rise to the intention to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment. They attained the stage of faith and peace of non-conceptualization;

When I was an animal, I did not forget the mind of a bodhisattva to extensively save others. I should have practiced to benefit others until now, but only for sentient beings who are suffering endlessly;
If there is even one person who has lost their original nature and is drowning without being rescued, I will never abandon them.
Those who wish to attain peace and these merits and quickly become Buddhas should all sincerely take refuge in the Three Jewels in their hearts, not abandoning them in any lifetime.
